title: Die wundersame Schustersfrau
text:
Die wundersame Schustersfrau ("The Wondrous Cobbler's Wife") is an opera in two acts by <a href="Udo%20Zimmermann">Udo Zimmermann</a>, with a libretto which he wrote with Eberhard Schmidt based on the 1930 Spanish play "<a href="La%20zapatera%20prodigiosa">La zapatera prodigiosa</a>", a "farsa violenta" by <a href="Federico%20Garc%C3%ADa%20Lorca">Federico García Lorca</a> and translated by Enrique Beck. The opera was first performed on 25 April 1982 at the <a href="Schlosstheater%20Schwetzingen">Schlosstheater Schwetzingen</a>, staged by <a href="Alfred%20Kirchner">Alfred Kirchner</a>.
History.
"Die wundersame Schustersfrau" is Zimmermann's fifth opera and the first not premiered in the <a href="German%20Democratic%20Republic">GDR</a>. He wrote it on a commission by the broadcaster <a href="S%C3%BCddeutscher%20Rundfunk">Süddeutscher Rundfunk</a> after the success of his opera "<a href="Der%20Schuhu%20und%20die%20fliegende%20Prinzessin">Der Schuhu und die fliegende Prinzessin</a>" at the 1977 <a href="Schwetzingen%20Festival">Schwetzingen Festival</a>. The libretto, based on 's German version of Lorca's "<a href="La%20zapatera%20prodigiosa">La zapatera prodigiosa</a>", was written by the composer and Lutz Eberhard Schmidt. Zimmermann completed the composition in 1981.
The premiere, as part of the Schwetzingen Festival at the <a href="Schlosstheater%20Schwetzingen">Schlosstheater Schwetzingen</a> on 25 April 1982, was produced by the <a href="Hamburg%20State%20Opera">Hamburg State Opera</a>, conducted by <a href="Peter%20G%C3%BClke">Peter Gülke</a> and staged by <a href="Alfred%20Kirchner">Alfred Kirchner</a>. During the same season, the opera was performed in <a href="Karlsruhe">Karlsruhe</a>, <a href="Bielefeld">Bielefeld</a> and the <a href="Leipzig%20Opera">Leipzig Opera</a>, the first performance in the GDR.
The stage director wrote a version suitable for small stages in 1985, which was performed in <a href="Bautzen">Bautzen</a>, <a href="Meiningen">Meiningen</a>, at the <a href="Staatstheater%20N%C3%BCrnberg">Staatstheater Nürnberg</a>, and in 1988 at the first <a href="Munich%20Biennale">Munich Biennale</a>. It was performed in Bonn in 1989 (conducted by the composer), <a href="Regensburg">Regensburg</a> in 1992, <a href="Klagenfurt">Klagenfurt</a> in 1993, and at the <a href="Deutsche%20Oper%20am%20Rhein">Deutsche Oper am Rhein</a> in Duisburg in 1996.
Music.
A critic of the premiere noted the opera's expressivity, beginning with a beginning of one central tone, intensified in rhythm and dynamics, a "chiffre" repeated in emotional situations. Other elements are fake-folklore, use of the <a href="celesta">celesta</a> reminiscent of Mozart, and repeated strong beats marking rage. Zimmermann wrote complex ensembles in octets of women.
Recording.
Excerpts from Act 2 were recorded as part of the series "" under the title "Nach- und Nachtgesänge – Oper 1977–1987 – Werke von Kirchner, U. Zimmermann, Matthus, W. Zimmermann, Rihm". As in the premiere, Peter Gülke conducted the <a href="Philharmonisches%20Staatsorchester%20Hamburg">Philharmonisches Staatsorchester Hamburg</a>.
